name: Endless Possibilities with Beacons / Custom Chat Bots for Google Home
description:
Talk 1: Endless Possibilities with Beacons

Duration: 20 min

With beacons being a up and coming technology , PJ will be showing all the possibilities that Google API's such as the Nearby Messaging API , Awareness API and Google beacon platform has to offer.

Speaker: P-J Welcome 

Speaker Bio:  P-J, who is based in Johannesburg, is a software developer that develops both Android and iOS apps. Everyone knows that he enjoys trying new and different technologies and being an explorer in the technology world. On a daily basis he works on a banking app, but also maintains an app called Digital Botanical Voucher Book and has started to contribute to the open source community.

Talk 2: Building Custom Chat Bots for the Google Home using API.AI

Duration: 40min

In this session, Rebecca will explain how to quickly and easily build a custom Google Actions for the Google Home by leveraging API.AI. 

Speaker: Rebecca Franks 

Speaker Bio: 

Rebecca is a Senior Android Developer and Google Developer Expert based in Johannesburg, South Africa. She loves working with new technology and has a passion for making great user friendly products. During the day she works on media streaming apps, helping to architect and implement new features. In her spare time, she manages her open source app, Book Dash, which contains free African story books. She speaks at conferences and local meetups mainly about Android. When not coding, she can be found blogging at riggaroo.co.za and travelling the world.

name: Developing Apps for Chromecast / Reactive Android Apps with RxJava
description:
Talk 1:  Developing apps for Chromecast

Duration: 20min

Delve into how you can add casting functionality within your Android app using the Google Cast SDK.

Speaker: Kurt Mbanje

Speaker Bio: Kurt is a mobile developer by profession. He currently works at DStv on their mobile apps team. 
He has worked on several mobile apps for Android with one of his own personal apps was featured by Google on the Plays Store. He’s a believer in open source and has several open source projects on GitHub. If he is not working on software he is either gaming, running or working on his Kendo technique.

-----------------------------------------

Talk 2: Reactive Android Apps with RxJava

Duration: 40 min

Speaker: Kamil Slesinski

This talk will present basic reactive programming concepts and focus on usage of RxJava 2. We will start with an introduction to basic building blocks: observables, subscribers and operators, and then move onto real-life usage examples.

Speaker Bio: Senior Android Developer currently based in Johannesburg, South Africa. Passionate about new technologies and making efficient and secure apps. With a rich background in Android OS development, currently focusing on DRM and media streaming apps. In his spare time can be found mountain biking or traveling around southern Africa.

name: Why Progressive Web Apps (PWAs) are the future / Motion for UI
description:
Talk 1 : Why Progressive Web Apps are the future (20min)

Are Progressive Web Apps ready to fill the shoes of native apps? Find out how Google's technologies such as Service Workers and Firebase are filling the gaps that we have been missing all this time.

Speaker: Francois van der Merwe

Francois is a web developer for Standard Bank, where he uses Angular 2 and some of the latest web technologies to develop state of the art web applications. He is also a qualified coffee to code converter and uses most of his spare time stroking his beard while staring at code.

Talk 2: Motion for UI (40 min)

A primer on animation and motion for applications and UI design, with principles that will help application developers and designers consider how to use this powerful medium to communicate, enthrall, and astound users, regardless of whether your application is something hip, or something square.

Speaker: Paul Hoets

Paul Hoets is a mobile developer at Fund Focus Mobile, and lives in South Korea. When he is not speaking Mandarin, messing with Arduino prototypes, and fitting solar panels, he is most likely browsing Dribbble.com and feeling depressed that such awesome animations are so hard to implement in real life. He is a wearer of many hats, of which Xamarin.Forms is his biggest at the moment. He is a devout Android.

name: Rapidly Fire up apps using Firebase | Make Neural Networks great again
description:
Talk 1 : Rapidly Fire up apps using Firebase (20min) 

Firebase is Google’s full stack NoSQL cloud platform that allows developers to build extraordinary realtime mobile and web apps.

In this session, Badi will take the audience through a brief introduction to Firebase followed by a live demo of building a real-world application using Firebase’s JavaScript API. The demo will showcase key features of the platform including realtime data synchronization, user authentication and session management, aiming to provide developers with a broad overview, but with enough depth to quickly get up and running with Firebase for their current and future projects.

Speaker: Badi Sudhakaran

Since beginning his career at Yahoo!, Badi has lived in four countries, worked for multi-national companies, led software teams and built beautiful software. Currently based in Johannesburg working as a consultant at IQ Business, Badi focuses on growing African businesses using technology by finding new and better ways of doing things. Badi is also an avid public speaker and has spoken several at developer user groups, local and international conferences including DevConf (South Africa), DevTalks (Romania) and CodeGarden (Denmark).

Talk 2: Make Neural Nets Great Again (40 min)

From modest perceptron to Deep Learning magic. A short history of Neural Networks, followed by discussion of deep learning concepts and working through code examples in TensorFlow ending the talk with a live Raspberry Pi demo classifying objects.

Speaker: Dries Cronje

Dries is a founding member of the Tracker Machine Learning team running with R&D projects from idea to production.

name: Google I/O Extended '17 - Joburg
description:
Join us for Google I/O Extended '17 Johannesburg Edition! In this special event meetup we will be running things a bit differently than usual. We will be live streaming the Google I/O event keynote! Google I/O is a developer festival located in Mountain View, California where the latest Google Technology announcements are made. 

Join us for the stream and some technical discussions with local developers. 

18:30 - Welcome Drinks and Snacks.

19:00 - 21:00 - Live Stream of the Google I/O Keynote session. 

The event will be hosted at JoziHub.

We look forward to welcoming everyone! Join in the conversation on twitter using the hashtag #io17extended and @GDGJohannesburg.

name: I/O Wrap Up | MVP on Android | Reactive Apps with Angular, RxJS, Socket.IO
description:
Back to normal with this months GDG Johannesburg meetup!  Join us for the following talks. 

We have 3 talks this month:

More info:

Talk 1: Google I/O 2017 Wrap Up (10min)

In this talk, Joshua will do a quick 10 min presentation of the things they enjoyed at Google I/O 2017. 

Speakers:  Joshua Leibstein

Talk 2: Avoiding broken bridges - a clean approach to Android applications (30min)

The talk will be looking at the Model View Presenter (MVP) pattern as a clean approach to structure Android applications in an attempt to ensure easy understanding of the codebase, as well as flexibility and maintainability.

Speaker: Patrick Kayongo

Patrick Kayongo is a Ugandan-born, South African-raised, Pan-African software developer with a passion for crafting software for the flourishing of communities, cities, countries and the African continent. When he's not developing software, he can be found spending time with his wife and son, reading good literature, or playing a musical instrument. 

Talk 3: Building Reactive Applications with Angular, RxJS and Socket.IO (40min)

We have been building client-server web applications using the same paradigms since bellbottoms, disco and IBM were popular. Everything since then has been a rehash of RPC and Request-Response, with JSON + REST being just the latest incarnation. We can do better. We now have the tools available to challenge those paradigms and build a new breed of application. Using reactive programming techniques and data streaming we can easily build rich, reactive web applications.
This code-oriented talk will show how to use Socket.IO to stream data to an Angular application. It will cover websocket basics, RxJS and working observables, as well as how it all seamlessly fits into Angular’s data-binding.

Speaker: Mike Geyser 

Speaker Bio: Mike Geyser is a programmer at BBD in the R&D team, specialising on designing and building for the web. He’s been hacking on the web since Geocities was a thing, has a long-lived love affair with JavaScript, and has (almost) come to terms with the fact that he will never have a programmer beard. While he has worked on some interesting large-scale enterprise applications, it is the challenges of the public web that really appeal to him - having earned his stripes on high volume transactional websites. He works primarily in JavaScript, C# and Java, and seldom refers to himself in the third person.

name: Google Appmaker | Building your first game using the Google VR SDK
description:
Join us for this meetup in July where we have two very interesting talks lined up. We have a talk on Virtual Reality with the Google VR SDK and building apps using Google AppMaker. 

Talk 1: Google AppMaker (20min)

App Maker is a low-code application development tool that lets your organisation build and deploy custom apps easily and securely, on the same platform that powers G Suite.
Join me in a walkthrough on this powerful tool.

Speaker: Mannetjie van Rooyen

Developer, Systems Architect, Big Data Analyst, AI enthusiast, Linux Lover, Electronics hobbyist, Martial artist, Bow Hunter, Super Dad and loving Husband. Passionate about Technology Life and Love. Oh yes and a avid book worm.  

Talk 2: Building your first game using the Google VR SDK (40min)

In this tutorial Joshua will show you how to get started building a Virtual Reality game using Unity, Blender and the Google VR SDK.

Speaker: Joshua Leibstein

Joshua is a Senior Android Developer at Standard Bank. He is meticulous and encourages good coding principles. In his spare time he enjoys learning about VR, game programming and making music.

name: Keep Calm and ES2017 | Gopherview
description:
Talk 1:  Keep Calm and ES2017 (20 min)

What is new and interesting with the ECMAScript[masked]th Edition language specification, few examples comparing the old and the new.

Speaker: Ruddy Riba

Ruddy is a software developer and a liker of all things tech, in her not being a big reader she is currently making her way through two books one about women as leaders and another on the fundamental difference between male and females. Co founder of an organisation called Pink-IT which is a movement of women in I.T aimed at creating a network to foster a culture and way of thinking for females in the software development field.

Talk 2: Gopherview (45 min)

Come join me as I give a nice broad overview of the Go language. The language is compact and small so we I will cover most of the the features along with examples and time permitted a full end to end, but small application demo to see what Go looks like in the wild. 

Speaker: Pieter Louw

Speaker Bio: I've been a software developer since 2001 and have worked with various languages (C,PHP, Java (Android) and C#) - the last year I've been working with Go. Open Source wise I only jumped in lately where I've made small contributions to the Caddy web server project through the TCP/UDP server plugin and a gRPC middleware plugin.

In parallel I am a husband and father to a boy and a girl.

name: Run Now,Install Later!(Android Instant Apps) | Practical gRPC (REST Alternative)
description:
Talk 1:
Title: Run Now, Install Later! (Android Instant Apps) (20min)
Google announced the general availability of Android Instant Apps at I/O 2017. In this session Charles walks you through the structure of an instant app and briefly discusses the building blocks of this exciting improvement in the way users engage with Native Android Apps. 

Speaker: Charles Okot
Charles Okot is a passionate Mobile Software Engineer currently working as an Android Developer at DVT.

Talk 2:
Title: Practical gRPC - (REST Alternative?)(45 min)
gRPC is a simple way to build web services/APIs, seen as REST's potential successor. In this talk, we will use gRPC instead of Retrofit on an Android app, as well as build a gRPC service. 

Speaker: Neville Dipale
I'm an accountant turned programmer, and have been developing for about 8 years.
I've got a "data engineering" background from my day-job, where I use Python, Kotlin JavaScript, and a few more other languages.
I'm also the founder of Moving Gauteng, which is a small public transit information website/app.

name: Getting Started with Polymer | Mastering Android ConstraintLayout
description:
GDG Johannesburg will host two talks in October:

Talk 1: Getting Started with Polymer 3.0 (20min)

Polymer is not just a framework, it is an ambitious attempt to scry into the future and inform the present - to steward and direct the evolution of the Web Platform. It has inextricably linked itself to Web Components, with the sole ambition of making them globally native. To be clear, this is a 'framework' that is actively courting its own obsolescence, growing smaller with every subsequent release.

It is in pursuit of this that the latest version of Polymer was announced, informed by recent W3C standardisation victories as well as mainstream adoption of Web Platform features. The project is removing features, changing the ecosystem, improving cross-framework interop, all to empower the platform.

This talk will give a brief overview of Polymer 3.0, the direction of WebComponents and make a case for why you should care about Polymer and the direction of the Web Platform.

Speaker: Mike Geyser

Speaker Bio:

Mike Geyser is a programmer at BBD in the R&D team, specialising on designing and building for the web. He’s been hacking on the web since Geocities was a thing, has a long-lived love affair with JavaScript, and has (almost) come to terms with the fact that he will never have a programmer beard. While he has worked on some interesting large-scale enterprise applications, it is the challenges of the public web that really appeal to him - having earned his stripes on high volume transactional websites. He works primarily in JavaScript, C# and Java, and seldom refers to himself in the third person.

Talk 2: Mastering Android ConstraintLayout (45min)

In this talk, Rebecca will demonstrate how to use ConstraintLayout when building Android Apps and some cool tricks you can do with it. From simplifying complex layouts to creating animations, ConstraintLayout has some really great usages. 

Speaker: Rebecca Franks

Speaker Bio: 

Rebecca Franks the Android Engineering Lead at DVT. She has over 5 years experience in developing Android applications.  In March 2016, she was awarded with the status of Google Developer Expert for Android.

In her spare time, she works with Book Dash – a Non Profit Organisation – developing an Android app to showcase their free children’s books. She enjoys public speaking and frequently speaks at conferences and local meetups.

Her blog has been featured multiple times in Android Weekly . In June 2016, She was selected as part of the Mail & Guardian’s Top 200 Young South Africans.

name: Android Things Workshop: Build Motion Sensing Lights & Camera
description:
GDG Johannesburg and GDG Cape Town are teaming up to offer an exciting Android Things session!

Android Things is an extension of the Android platform for IoT and embedded devices, writing IoT apps has been made a lot easier using Android Things. In this workshop, we will first cover what Android Things is and some basic examples of how to use it and then we will go onto building a light powered by motion sensor. Then you will learn to build a motion sensing camera that will take images and send them to your phone.

IMPORTANT Prerequisites:

- Programming experience required (ie Java development experience or similar, ideally have done Android development before)

- You will just need to bring a laptop that has :

- Android Studio 3.0 beta 6 (or higher) installed on it. (See here for how to get the Android Studio preview)

- The laptop needs a USB A port on it (ie if you have a new MacBook you need to print an adapter). 

Please note we will have Android Things kits and all the required peripherals needed for development.

You will be working in pairs as we have a limited number of kits available. As such, we are accepting a maximum of 30 attendees. Please only RSVP as attending if you are certain that you will be able to make it!

Light drinks and snacks will be provided.

For more context, we will be building this hackster.io project

name: Last meetup for 2017! "Android Development with Kotlin" and "A Web of Things"
description:
We've had a great year of meetups and enjoyed sharing knowledge and helping the developer community grow and learn. 

For our last meetup of 2017, we will have two talks. Please join us in celebrating a great year of knowledge sharing and community growth :)

Talk 1: Re-inventing Android development with Kotlin (40min) 

This is an introductory talk on Kotlin, covering language features and syntax.

Speaker: Tashinga Pemhiwa

Speaker Bio: Tashinga Nathan Pemhiwa is a software developer who has dabbled in various languages from Delphi and VB 6 to Java to PHP and JavaScript. He is excited to see newcomers like Kotlin changing the way we think about and write code. He lives with his wife and four children in the Jacaranda city. 

Talk 2: A Web of Things (45min)

Devices, smart devices everywhere. This is what our world is turning into. Your car tells you how to drive, your watch tells you when to exercise, and your phone tells you when you are hungry. OK, maybe that last bit is a little over the top, but I’m sure someone will make an app like that soon. All of this is controlled by applications which use Bluetooth and Wi-Fi to connect and communicate with each other. However, this is never enough for us as developers, we need to be in control.

The Chrome dev team started the Physical Web movement with the intention of making everything smarter. With Web Bluetooth we can control almost any Bluetooth Low Energy device from a website. No longer dependent on the platform we are using or on apps which require installation or updates. All we need is a browser which supports it.

This talk will cover some of the fundamental concepts of connecting to BLE devices using Chrome and broadcasting from BLE beacons, including the privacy and security considerations. It will go into some coding examples of how this can be done using the Angular bluetooth module. 

Speaker: Gergana Young

Speaker Bio: Software developer, adventurer, and Star Wars geek extraordinaire. Intending on making a career of reprogramming astromech droids with JavaScript, she abandoned the Imperial Academy and defected to BBD. After a tour of duty in the banking sector, working on .NET, JavaScript, Angular and Meteor, she finally found her place in the R&D team. In her spare time she builds cool software and things for her other passions: rock climbing, running and, of course, Star Wars.

name: February Meetup - Firebase Cloud Functions | The Google Cloud loves sensor data
description:
First meetup of 2018!
Date: 7th February 2018
Time: 18:00 - 20:00

The meetup is hosted at JoziHub in 44 Stanley. Parking is available in the street or in the centre across the road.

Talk 1: Introduction to Cloud Functions for Firebase (25 min)
This talk will be an introduction to Firebase Cloud Functions, what they are, how they fit into the Firebase suite of products and how we can use them to build better apps. Cloud functions are mainly written in JavaScript but this presentation will show how we can also write our cloud functions in KotlinJS.

Speaker: Peter-John Welcome
Peter-John is a mobile developer at Dynamic Visual Technologies, developing a banking app for one of South Africa’s biggest banks. He works on both Android and iOS platforms and enjoys using new technologies and APIs. Big Kotlin and Swift fan. In his spare time, he's into photography, blogging about technology and co-organising developer meetups at GDG Johannesburg.

Talk 2: The Google Cloud loves sensor data. (45min)
In this talk, Dries will demonstrate how to use webhooks to stream sensor data from a Particle Photon to the Google Cloud.

Speaker: Dries Cronje
As a Deep Learning Research Engineer at Tracker Dries is involved in both the design and implementation of deep learning systems and the integration with existing systems. He stays on top of the field by researching all the latest technological advancements.

name: Fantastic chatbots and where to find them | Up and Running with Kubernetes
description:
- Date: 7th March 2018
- Time: 18:00 - 20:00

This meetup we have two very interesting talks scheduled. Fantastic Chatbots and a talk about Kubernetes. Please be sure to join us! More information about the talks below:

Talk 1: Fantastic chatbots and where to find them
Arrie and Simon dream romantically about being able to converse with their machines. These voice and text-based interfaces are making their way into our products and it turns out, are actually simple to build.

We will give you a ridiculously short, principled understanding of natural language processing, using Google's DialogFlow and Cloud Functions, while building a chatbot that can handle registering a user for your site and responding to small talk. As a bonus let’s control our root.co.za account with our voice, for reals. Let’s explore this together as we share our foray into text-based interfaces & how we can apply them right now.

Speaker: Simon Van Dyk and Arrie Pieterse

Simon is a technical product lead at Platform45, interested in everything software from design & development to machine learning. On his journey, Simon loves sharing his learnings, and has given a couple talks in South Africa and the USA. Catch him on Github (@sighmin), or at simonvandyk.co.za.

Arrie is a developer at Platform45 passionate about the intersection of design and innovative technologies ranging from chatbots and voice interfaces to machine learning and DAPPs. Catch him on Github (@klipie245), or at 500px.com/klipie245.

Talk 2: Up and Running with Kubernetes

How do I manage an application at scale?

That’s a common question facing developers today.

With modern web services, users expect applications to be available 24/7, and developers expect to deploy new versions of those applications several times a day.

Containerization helps package software to serve these goals, enabling applications to be released and updated in an easy and fast way without downtime.

Googles’ Kubernetes helps you make sure those containerized applications run where and when you want and helps them find the resources and tools they need to work.

In this talk, we'll get up and running with Kubernetes to deploy, scale, and manage your distributed container-based applications.

Speaker: Rory Preddy

For 20 years Rory has developed and designed distributed enterprise systems.
He works full time in Research which gives him an unparalleled insight into industry movement.
For fun, he runs the Java, AWS and Kotlin User groups and races microservice driven cars.

name: IWD Women TechMakers Talks | Building an artificial John Lennon with Keras
description:
In April we will be highlighting Women in Tech for International Women's Day celebrations! #IWD18

This event is primarily for ladies although everyone is welcome - the speakers will all be female talking about Google related technologies.
More information will be provided soon - but rough outline so far:

17:00 - Welcome Drinks and Snacks
17:30 - Intro to GDG & Women in Tech event welcome!
18:05 - Talk 1 (15 min) -What the hell is UX and Human Centred Design anyway? (Niki De Bruyn)
18:25 - Talk 2 (15 min) - Enhancing your app with Firebase (Mbalenhle Ndaba)
19:00 - Talk 3 (45 min) - Building an artificial John Lennon with Keras (Jade Abbott)
19:45 - End Drinks and Prizes

Talk 1: “What the hell is UX and Human Centred Design anyway?”

A lot of industries are in a digital panic mode, everyone knows that digital is the way to go but how do we get there? How do we beat the rest and do it well and fast? This is when the terms 'Design Lead', 'User Experience' and 'Human Centered Design' start making an appearance. What makes this way of developing products so important? How do we as the Engineers, Designers and Product Owners deal with budgets, crazy deadlines, skepticism, delivering at scale and getting business to buy in? How do we create interfaces that make a user fall in love with our products and why are design guidelines like Google Material Design important in making a user feel at ease?

This talk will be about unpacking the minefield that is product development and finding ways that we can make our mark, as a development and design team (we are in the same boat) so that we can have an impact and make magic.

Speaker: Niki De Bruyn

Niki is a Senior User Experience Designer at DVT. After getting her degree in Psychology and Criminology and unsuccessfully becoming a crime fighting phenomenon, she found her love for solving human problems through technology and design. There is nothing that she loves more than taking on a challenge and task that users don't really enjoy doing and turning it into something that makes things just a little bit easier to handle. Niki has worked on the Absa MegaU Kids Banking App, Absa Mobile Banking App, Vodacom E-Schools and My Top Dog Education platforms. She has also facilitated a number of Google Venture Design Sprints

Talk 2: Enhancing your app with Firebase
Exploring the different features on Firebase and how they can be used in your app.

Speaker: Mbalenhle Ndaba (https://twitter.com/NdabaMbalenhle)

Mbalenhle is a Mobile Developer at DVT. She enjoys learning new tech. She attended the 2017 Firebase Dev Summit through Google's Women Techmakers program which provides visibility, support and empowers women in the tech industry.

Talk 3: Building an artificial John Lennon with Keras (45 min)
We live in a world where amazing APIs have made it easy to play in complex fields such as AI. Francois Chollet's Keras is one of those libraries that makes working with complex neural networks a breeze. The talk aims to give an intuitive understanding of machine learning (specifically for working with natural language), introduce you to Keras, and then demonstrate how to train an AI to write songs like The Beatles. Speaker: Jade Abbott (https://twitter.com/alienelf)

Jade Abbott is a Senior Software Developer and Data Scientist at Retro Rabbit. Since 2013, she's built software for every field from social upliftment to banking, working on projects throughout Africa. She's worked at every end of software (with a particular preference for backend) and considers herself a polyglot. Since then, her focus has shifted to her lifelong passion - AI and data science. Her current project involves training deep learning models to perform a variety of NLP tasks for real-life systems. She has recently completed her MSc in Swarm Robotics and as a published researcher has presented her research locally and abroad. When she is not wrangling data, she plays bass for South African instrumental band Follow Me Follow You.

name: Google I/O Extended '18 - Joburg
description:
Join us for Google I/O Extended '18 Johannesburg Edition! In this special event meetup we will be running things a bit differently than usual. We will be live streaming the Google I/O event keynote! Google I/O is a developer festival located in Mountain View, California where the latest Google Technology announcements are made.

Join us for the stream and some technical discussions with local developers.

18:30 - Welcome Drinks and Snacks.

19:00 - 21:00 - Live Stream of the Google I/O Keynote session.

name: When is it ok to go hybrid and when is it a death wish | Design tips for Android
description:
Date: 6th June 2018
Time: 18:00 - 20:00

GDG Johannesburg will host two talks in June:

Talk 1 : "When is it okay to go hybrid, and when is it a death wish"

Given the "multi-platform" nature of building a hybrid app, much of the world is tempted to use something like React Native or Xamarin. But, in a world where Android dev has kotlin and iOS dev is eased up by swift (and... now also kotlin), should we really be so tempted?

Speaker: Kimberleigh Beyl
(www.linkedin.com/in/kimberleigh-beyl-93bab3b9)

Talk 2 : Design for developers: design tips for Android

This talk will look at practical examples of how design principles can be used in combination with Material design principles to create a better user experience on Android platforms. It's an introduction to design fundamentals and good practices.

Speaker: Lizette Spangenberg
(https://www.linkedin.com/in/lizette-spangenberg-a8850b20/
)

name: Building performance optimised web apps in 2018 | Your first ARCore app in Unity
description:
July looks to be an interesting one!
Join us for two talks:

Talk 1 (20min) Your first ARCore app in Unity
Speaker : Joshua Leibstein
https://twitter.com/JoshLiebe

Talk 2 (40min) Building performance optimized web apps in 2018
A story of how Angular met Firebase and together bore a baby named Service Worker.

Speaker: Richard Sithole
https://about.me/richard.sithole

name: MotionLayout in Android | Android Developer's Guide to Machine Learning
description:
In August we are focused on Android! 🤖Looking into the new MotionLayout announced at Google I/O 2018, as well as ML Kit and TensorFlow Lite. 🧠

Have you ever wanted to create your own Hot Dog or Not App? 🌭 Well, then this meetup is for you. Rebecca will be talking about using MLKit and TensorFlow Lite. Kurt will be talking about MotionLayout.😃

AGENDA:
17:45 - 18:10 - Food and Drinks are served, get comfy and prepare yourself to learn some new things!
18:10 - 18:15 - Welcome to GDG!
18:15 - 18:40 - MotionLayout on Android - Kurt Mbanje https://twitter.com/ckurtm
18:40 - 18:45 - Small Breather
18:45 - 19:30 - Android Developer's Guide to Machine Learning with MLKit and TensorFlow Lite - Rebecca Franks https://twitter.com/riggaroo
19:30 - 19:45 - Giveaways and Thanks!

LOCATION:
JoziHub, 44 Stanley.

WHAT TO EXPECT:
Lots of great content and smart developers! (Oh and some awesome prizes to be won!)

WHAT TO BRING:
Yourself, and maybe a friend if you are shy to chat to people (don't be shy!)

ABOUT JOZIHUB:
JoziHub is a co-working spot located in 44 Stanley. You can find more about their venue here: http://jozihub.org/

Please remember, we have a code of conduct at our meetup. Everyone is welcome and if you feel uncomfortable please let any of the organisers know.
how_to_find_us: Go into 44 Stanley and head to the back. JoziHub is at the back past Salvation Cafe. Go up the stairs to the 3rd Floor where JoziHub Coworking space is.

name: Navigation Architecture Component | Building an Android Chatbot App (DialogFlow)
description:
In September we are still focused on Android! 🤖Looking into the new Navigation Architecture Component announced at Google I/O 2018, as well as Building an Android Chatbot App with DialogFlow.

AGENDA:

name: Workbox Wizardry (Service Workers) | Frida - Dynamic instrumentation toolkit
description:
In October we have a talk on Workbox Wizardry for the Web developers and a look at Frida - a dynamic instrumentation toolbox for mobile developers ! 🤖

AGENDA:
17:45 - 18:10 - Food and Drinks are served, get comfy and prepare yourself to learn some new things!

18:10 - 18:15 - Welcome to GDG!

18:15 - 18:40 - Frida - Dynamic instrumentation toolkit - Christoff Jacobs

When writing an Android mobile application displaying sensitive information to the end-user. Care has to be taken by the developer to safeguard against individuals, who intends to by-pass such validation checks. In bypassing the validation checks the sensitive information can be viewed or accessed.

This talk will demonstrate the steps required by a developer to potentially by-pass such validation checks using the Frida toolkit.

18:40 - 18:45 - Small Breather

18:45 - 19:30 - Workbox Wizardry - Mike Geyser

Service workers are powerful features of modern web experiences that seem like a whole bunch of black magic to the uninitiated. A proliferation of frameworks, an array of browser APIs, and a slew of tools all combine to cast a pall of confusion over the topic. Never fear; we will use the incredible Workbox library (and tools) to dispel all shadows of doubt, and confidently build service workers.

This code-oriented talk takes an extensive look at the different ways workbox can be used. It shows different pre- and runtime-caching strategies, explains the challenges behind service worker life cycle events, and explores offline strategies using background sync. It will even show you how workbox can be used on traditional server-side websites - giving them a real performance boost. So come along, level up, and add a few more incantations to your spellbook.
19:30 - 19:45 - Giveaways and Thanks!

LOCATION:
JoziHub, 44 Stanley.

WHAT TO EXPECT:
Lots of great content and smart developers! (Oh and some awesome prizes to be won!)

WHAT TO BRING:
Yourself, and maybe a friend if you are shy to chat to people (don't be shy!)

ABOUT JOZIHUB:
JoziHub is a co-working spot located in 44 Stanley. You can find more about their venue here: http://jozihub.org/

Please remember, we have a code of conduct at our meetup. Everyone is welcome and if you feel uncomfortable please let any of the organisers know.
how_to_find_us: Go into 44 Stanley and head to the back. JoziHub is at the back past Salvation Cafe. Go up the stairs to the 3rd Floor where JoziHub Coworking space is.

name: AutoML FTW | Speech Synthesis with Tensorflow and Wavenet
description:
In November we have a talk on AutoML a way to do machine learning without any coding and Speech Synthesis with Tensorflow and Wavenet ! 🤖

AGENDA:
17:45 - 18:10 - Food and Drinks are served, get comfy and prepare yourself to learn some new things!

18:10 - 18:15 - Welcome to GDG!

18:15 - 18:40 - AutoML FTW - Peter-John Welcome

This will be an introduction to a Google Cloud Product called AutoML. This products gives people the ability to create custom machine learning models without any coding or coding experience.

We will look at what AutoML has to offer and some examples of how it could be useful.

18:40 - 18:45 - Small Breather

18:45 - 19:30 - Speech Synthesis with Tensorflow and Wavenet - Vusi Moyo

A brief intro to how speech is generated using a machine learning library like Tensorflow, with reference to Wavenet. From preparing your model data to training, then generating some samples.

I will also show how to get that model to work with TFLite for Android for your own sample voice synthesis app.

19:30 - 19:45 - Giveaways and Thanks!

name: GDG DevFest South Africa 2018
description:
The event is a bit different from other conferences. We want to make it accessible so we aren't charging a fee to attend.

There are only 200 spots so you need to really give some good motivation as to why you want to be there. APPLY TO ATTEND HERE : http://devfest.co.za.

NOTE: RSVP’ing ON MEETUP DOES NOT MEAN YOU HAVE A TICKET TO ATTEND.

name: Toward a better code review culture | Machine Learning capabilities with MLKit
description:
For our first meet-up of the year we have a talk on code review culture by Pamela Hill and a talk about MLKit by Mbalenhle Ndaba who were both speakers at Devfest South Africa at the end of last year. 🤖

AGENDA:
17:45 - 18:00 - Food and Drinks are served, get comfy and prepare yourself to learn some new things!

18:00 - 18:15 - Welcome to GDG! Whats new in 2019

18:15 - 18:45 - Toward a better code review culture - Pamela Hill

A healthy code review culture can produce several positive results: improved communication, better software quality, and mutual accountability. But an unhealthy code review culture can break down individuals and a team. Pamela will discuss her own experiences with code reviews, and give tips on how to encourage a healthy code review culture in your team.

18:40 - 18:45 - Small Breather

18:45 - 19:30 - How I built an App with Machine Learning capability using Firebase MLKit - Mbalenhle Ndaba

Machine Learning is one of the most popular and interesting topics in tech at the moment. Everyone is talking about it, everyone wants to use it. I will be using the Firebase MLKit (beta) to build an app that leverages the power of Machine Learning. I will be sharing my experience of using Firebase MLKit, from how easy it was to integrate it, to the challenges I came across, as well as the limitations of Firebase MLKit and how to work around them.

19:30 - 19:45 - Giveaways and Thanks!
